Here's to 20 more years of open source multimedia! :tada: <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EpsdMUQU8AAA7ZI.png>

messages.text: When recording videos from a camera, is there a way to deal with temporal inconsistencies with the incoming frames? For instance, the next frame might be delayed because of other processes hogging the CPU, and a frame is encoded with the wrong time-stamp. What's the best way to deal with something like this?

elements.text: When recording videos from a camera, is there a way to deal with temporal inconsistencies with the incoming frames? For instance, the next frame might be delayed because of other processes hogging the CPU, and a frame is encoded with the wrong time-stamp. What's the best way to deal with something like this?

messages.text: Your camera is not timestamping the frames itself?  What kind of camera are you talking about?

elements.text: Your camera is not timestamping the frames itself?  What kind of camera are you talking about?

messages.text: This is a picam on a raspberry pi. But I'm referring to the <https://juliaio.github.io/VideoIO.jl/stable/writing/#Iterative-Encoding|Iterative Encoding> VideoIO does. It only takes the frame and it's index, not its timestamp. And when sequentially reading frames off of a camera I have no control over the amount of time that passes from one read and the next.

elements.text: This is a picam on a raspberry pi. But I'm referring to the

VideoIO does. It only takes the frame and it's index, not its timestamp. And when sequentially reading frames off of a camera I have no control over the amount of time that passes from one read and the next.

messages.text: Right, another attack angle: say I have a pipe that streams video (from some system call to ffmpeg or raspivid), is there a way for VideoIO to accept that as a AVInput?

elements.text: Right, another attack angle: say I have a pipe that streams video (from some system call to ffmpeg or raspivid), is there a way for VideoIO to accept that as a AVInput?

messages.text: Turns out VideoIO and ImageInTerminal play nicely together..

messages.text:
How can I use FFMPEG_jll or FFMPEG to pipe a ffmpeg command?
Using the system's ffmpeg I'd do something like this:
```io = open(`ffmpeg -i ... `)```
but how would I do that without using the system's ffmpeg?
